title: Fortinet firewalls exposed by active exploitation of critical vulnerabilities
executive_summary: Multiple Fortinet vulnerabilities in FortiGate, FortiOS, FortiProxy, FortiSwitchManager, and FortiWeb are being actively exploited by threat actors. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}
The flaws allow bypass of authentication and administrative access, exposing firewall management interfaces and sensitive configuration data. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}
what_happened: Security researchers and incident responders observed exploitation of authentication bypass vulnerabilities affecting Fortinet products. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}
CVE-2025-59718 and CVE-2025-59719 were added to the U.S. CISA Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog due to confirmed real-world attacks. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}

Attackers used crafted Security Assertion Markup Language (SAML) messages to authenticate as administrators, allowing unauthorized access to systems and configuration exports. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}
who_is_affected: Organizations using Fortinet FortiGate firewalls and related products globally. :contentReference[oaicite:5]{index=5}
Networks with exposed management interfaces accessible from the public internet. :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}
Teams relying on FortiCloud SSO without segregated internal management access. :contentReference[oaicite:7]{index=7}
attack_flow: Threat actor targets authentication bypass vulnerability in FortiOS, FortiProxy, FortiSwitchManager, or FortiWeb. :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}
Crafted SAML or authentication messages bypass SSO and grant administrative access. :contentReference[oaicite:9]{index=9}
Attacker exports firewall configuration and potentially extracts sensitive network information. :contentReference[oaicite:10]{index=10}
Unauthorized access may lead to further network compromise or persistence.
business_impact: Unauthorized administrative access to firewall devices. :contentReference[oaicite:11]{index=11}
Exposure of sensitive configuration files, including credentials and network topology. :contentReference[oaicite:12]{index=12}
Increased risk of lateral network attacks and data exfiltration. :contentReference[oaicite:13]{index=13}
risk_reason: Vulnerabilities that allow authentication bypass or unauthorized admin access on perimeter devices like firewalls pose systemic risk, undermining network defenses at a foundational level. :contentReference[oaicite:14]{index=14}
what_usually_goes_wrong: Firewall management interfaces left exposed to the internet. :contentReference[oaicite:15]{index=15}
Slow patching and failure to apply security advisories promptly. :contentReference[oaicite:17]{index=17}

immediate: Apply available security patches for all affected Fortinet products. :contentReference[oaicite:18]{index=18}
Restrict management interface access to internal or secured admin networks. :contentReference[oaicite:19]{index=19}
short_term: Disable FortiCloud SSO where not required or enforce strict authentication policies. :contentReference[oaicite:20]{index=20}
Audit current firewall configurations for unauthorized changes. :contentReference[oaicite:21]{index=21}
long_term: Implement network segmentation and zero-trust principles for management access. :contentReference[oaicite:22]{index=22}
Integrate vulnerability scanning and automated patch management. :contentReference[oaicite:23]{index=23}

what_this_does_not_mean: All Fortinet deployments are fully compromised by default — risk depends on configuration and exposure. :contentReference[oaicite:24]{index=24}
All firewalls are breached — only unpatched, exposed devices are at immediate risk. :contentReference[oaicite:25]{index=25}

signs: Unexpected administrative logins or configuration exports. :contentReference[oaicite:26]{index=26}
alerts: Multiple failed or successful admin login attempts from unfamiliar IPs. :contentReference[oaicite:28]{index=28}
Configuration file downloads outside scheduled maintenance windows. :contentReference[oaicite:29]{index=29}
